授業方法:
This course is to be delivered as interactive online seminars after the first week when we meet in class. If we need to change the teaching delivery mode, advanced notice will be announced via LUNA. PLEASE CHECK LUNA CONSTANTLY AS STUDENTS WILL HAVE OPEN ACCESS TO LUNA EVEN BEFORE FORMAL REGISTRATION. All the readings, instructions and other communication will be transmitted via LUNA.
ONCE YOU ARE FORMALLY ENROLLED, YOU CAN SUBMIT YOUR ASSIGNMENTS VIA LUNA. UNTIL THEN, PLEASE KEEP ALL ASSIGNMENTS IN YOUR OWN FILE.
Read all of the assigned readings and other online materials and submit all the assignments online. (For those who are interested in further readings, a list of advanced readings is provided. These are not required readings but provide the students with the opportunity to deepen their understanding of the subject and will be useful references for further studies.) Students will be given different reading assignments according to their interest, the level of their study, discipline and credit transfer requirements.

評価.教科書Required texts0: Nil. Students are encouraged to read widely on the subject including periodicals and academic journals. Theoretical foundation is based on Chap.2, in T. Mito, State Power and Multinational Oil Corporations: The Political Economy of Market Intervention in Canada and Japan (Fukuoka, Japan: Kyushu University Press, 2001). It is based on a chapter submitted as a doctoral thesis in law to the University of Tsukuba. As it is available on line, we use its original chapter as a required reading.
評価.参考文献・資料Reference books0: The course uses online and other studies uploaded via LUNA. Please check LUNA for further instructions. Classical studies include: Frederic C. Deyo, The Political Economy of the New Asian Industrialism (Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1987); Chung H. Lee and Ippei Yamazawa (eds.), The Economic Development of Japan and Korea: A Prallel with Lessons (New York: Praeger, 1990);; Pietro P. Masina, Rethinking Development in East Asia (London: Curzon, 2002): Kenneth L. Judd and Young Ki Lee (eds.), An Agenda for Economic Reform in Korea: International Perspectives (Stanford: Hoover Institution, Stanford University, 2000); Robert Wade, Governing the Market: Economic Theory and the Role of Government in East Asian Industrialization (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1990); Alvin Y. So and Stephen K.W. Chiu, East Asia and the World Economy (London: Sage Publications, 1995); and Yumei Zhang, Pacific Asia: The Politics of Development (New York: Routledge, 2003).
